title: How to Organize Your Photos

steps.headline: Transfer photos on your phone, flash drives, and online to your desktop.
steps.description: Create a new folder on your desktop. You can label this folder “External Photos” or some other name so that you don’t forget what it is. Collect every external hard drive that you own and plug them into your computer one at a time. Cut every photo on your external drives and paste them into your new folder. The goal is to get photos into one location to make sorting easier. If you have any CDs with photos on them, sort through these as well.

steps.headline: Pull up every folder with photos in them on your computer.
steps.description: Go through your computer files and find every folder with images in them. Either keep the individual folders up while you work, or cut and paste all of the images into a single folder.Tip: If you have images on multiple computers, transfer the images from the other computers with a flash drive. Store all of these images on the newest computer you own since an older computer is more likely to break down or crash. If your computer’s folders are already sorted, don’t combine them. It will be easier to sort them if they’re already separated logically.

steps.headline: Delete blurry images and photos that don’t matter to you.
steps.description: Change your viewing mode so that the photos appear as large thumbnails in your folders. Go through each folder and delete any images that are blurry, unnecessary, or don’t hold any value to you. If you don’t have a good reason for holding on to these images, there’s no reason to let them take up space on your computer. You can store these images on a spare flash drive if you’re really worried about accidentally deleting something important.

steps.headline: Create a sequence of chronological folders to sort your images by date.
steps.description: Create a new, empty folder to store all of your images in one place. Inside of this folder, create a new folder for every year represented in your photo collection. Inside of each year’s folder, create additional subfolders for the events that took place each year. Alternatively, you can create a folder for every month of the year. This can make it hard to find images if you don’t have a good memory, though. For example you could have a folder labelled “2012.” Inside of this folder, you can add folders with names like “January,” “January-April,” or “January Amy’s Family Gathering.” When you pick a labeling system, use it consistently across the board to keep things consistent.

steps.headline: Sort your images into folders based on subject matter to find photos easily.
steps.description: Put photos from specific vacations, weddings, parties, and family gatherings in different folders. Label each folder with a short description of the event or use the names of the people in the images.Tip: This is the best option if you don’t necessarily know when photos were taken or you find it more intuitive. There are no right or wrong ways to do this, so choose the method that makes the most sense to you. Label folders with keywords, not complete sentences. For example, you may have a folder named “Vacation Malaysia Jennifer and Steve,” but stay away from labels like “Summer trip to Malaysia with Jennifer and Steve.”

steps.headline: Put numbers in front of your labels to arrange them in order.
steps.description: Computer files are always arranged alphabetically by default. This makes organizing your folders harder, since “April” will appear in front of “January" and your description labels won’t be chronological. To keep the images in order, put a 2- or 3-digit number in front of each folder to arrange them in a way that makes sense to you. For example, if “Vacation Malaysia Jennifer and Steve” is the oldest set of images, name it “001 Vacation Malaysia Jennifer and Steve.” If you’re sorting images chronologically, use  “001 January,” “002 February,” and so on. Whether you use 2- or 3-digit numerical labels depends on how many folders you have. Even if you use keywords to sort your subfolders, you should still try to keep the images relatively chronological. It will be much easier to find what you’re looking for when you go to find an image.

steps.headline: Backup your images online or on a separate hard drive.
steps.description: In the event that your computer crashes permanently, you’ll want to have a backup of your images. Copy your photos and paste them in a separate external hard drive, or upload them to an online cloud service.Tip: You can use a cloud service as your primary storage option if you’d like, but it’s a good idea to keep a copy on a computer or external hard drive in the event that your cloud account gets hacked or you get locked out somhow. Popular online storage options include iDrive, pCloud, and Flickr. You can also use a general storage service, like Dropbox or Google Drive. Back your images up online and on an external hard drive to completely ensure that nothing happens to your images.

steps.headline: Store the images on an external hard drive to save space.
steps.description: Photographs take up a ton of space on a computer and you may not go through your images very frequently. To save storage space, get an external hard drive or flash drive and move your images to the new drive. Label the drive with a piece of tape and a marker so that you can easily find your images in the future. Whenever you want to look at your photos, plug the hard drive into the computer. If you only have a few hundred images, you can keep your images on a 16-32 gb flash drive. If you have a large number of photographs, get a standalone hard drive. If you have thousands of images, a 250-500 gb hard drive should provide plenty of space. A terabyte can hold roughly 1.5 million videos if you need to store a massive number of images.

steps.headline: Keep a copy on your computer to easily access your images.
steps.description: Leave your organized folder on the desktop if you want to easily access your photos whenever you want. You can also leave the folder in the “Photos” folder on your hard drive. If you have a specific file location where you store other media, you can also keep your photos there. If your computer ever crashes and you lose the photos on your computer, copy your backup folder and put it on your new computer when you get one.

steps.headline: Collect all of your photos and set them out on a table for sorting.
steps.description: Clear a large table off and wipe it down with a dry cloth. Go through your old drawers, folders, and shoe boxes to find loose photos that need sorting. Remove images from your scrapbooks and albums if you want to re-sort them. Set all of your photos out on the table face up to keep them from getting scratched on the table.Tip: If your pictures are especially old or you really want to protect the photos, wear nitrile gloves to avoid damaging or leaving fingerprints on your fingers. If you have any albums or scrapbooks that you’re happy with, you can leave these photos where they are.

steps.headline: Sort through the images and make a pile of prints that you want to keep.
steps.description: Shuffle through your stack of photographs and create 2 piles—photos that you want to keep and photos to toss out. Getting rid of blurry, uninteresting, or damaged photos streamlines your collection and makes the organization part much easier! If you have specific images that you plan on framing or putting into a preexisting album, put them into a third pile to handle them separately. If you don’t care about the order of the images, don’t worry about making a neat pile for the images you’re keeping. If the photos are already sorted chronologically, stack related photos together to make sorting easier. If you have copies of any photos, give away the duplicates to friends and family members that may be interested in them. If you have hundreds of photos, this may take you several days.

steps.headline: Group similar photos together and arrange them chronologically.
steps.description: Go through your keep pile an additional time and start moving photos around to make images easier to find. Put older photos at the back of the pile and place newer images near the front. Put photos from the same event, trip, or location together in your stack to make your pile consistent and easier to sort. You don’t have to do this if the order of your images doesn’t matter to you.

steps.headline: Write details or dates on the back of each photo as you sort if you’d like.
steps.description: If you come across any photos of old family members, holidays, or special events, jot a little note on the back of the image. If you remember the date, write the year on the back of the image as well. Be sure to use an acid-free pencil to avoid damaging your photos. You don’t have to do this, but it’s a good idea if you have a lot of older photos that your family members may be interested in or there are specific details that you don’t want to forget.

steps.headline: Frame any photos that you want to save on your walls.
steps.description: Count the number of images that you want to save on your wall and purchase frames from an art supply or framing store. Insert your images into frames and hang them up in your home so you can look at them whenever you want. You can either hang them next to other paintings and photos in your home, or fill a new wall and store them together to create a gallery wall. Most photos from disposable cameras are 4 by 6 inches (10 by 15 cm) or 5 by 7 inches (13 by 18 cm). If all of your images are the same size, measure one of them use this as a reference when you go to buy your frames.

steps.headline: Store memorable images in photo albums to keep them safe.
steps.description: Purchase photo albums with protective plastic pages for the images that are important but not worth memorializing on your wall. You can either pick up a single album to store all of your photos in one place, or get a separate album for different periods, events, or memories.Tip: Buy your photo albums online or from a local craft store. Keep in mind that different albums hold images of different sizes, so measure your photos before picking albums up.

steps.headline: Pack less important photos in acid-free envelopes and label them.
steps.description: Pick up acid-free envelopes designed from a craft or photography store. Put photos that you don’t want to preserve on the wall or in a photo album in the envelopes. Stack the photos so that they all face the same direction and fold the top of each envelope over to close it. Label each envelope with a short description or date to keep track of the contents. You can also buy large storage boxes lined with acid-free cardboard and paper if you want to store all of your photos in one location. Store your envelopes in a dark location that won’t drop below 40 °F (4 °C) or exceed 80 °F (27 °C).

steps.headline: Scan your photos if you want to preserve them digitally.
steps.description: If you want to ensure that your photos don’t go missing or get damaged, scan them to your computer to create a digital backup. You can scan all of your images, or scan a handful of images you want to save. You can pay a digitization service to do this for you. This is a good choice if you have hundreds of images and don’t want to spend hours scanning images on the computer.
